attachments: Diagram of fermenter labeled with letters P, Q, R, S, T, U showing various components

subparts.question_text: Explain why doctors give antibiotics to people who are ill.
subparts.hint: Think about what antibiotics do to bacteria and why bacteria are harmful
subparts.explanation: Antibiotics kill or damage bacteria and other pathogens that cause illness. They can also prevent the growth and reproduction of harmful microorganisms.

subparts.question_text: Explain why it is important to complete a full treatment of antibiotics.

correct_answers.answer: all bacteria need to be killed
all bacteria need to be destroyed
new antibiotics have to be developed

subparts.hint: Consider what happens if some bacteria survive the treatment
subparts.explanation: Completing the full course ensures all bacteria are killed. If treatment is stopped early, surviving bacteria can multiply and may develop antibiotic resistance.

parts.question_text: Penicillin was discovered in 1928 by Alexander Fleming. Name the type of microorganism that produces the antibiotic penicillin.
parts.hint: Think about what organism Fleming observed contaminating his bacterial culture
parts.explanation: Penicillin is produced by the fungus Penicillium (specifically Penicillium notatum or Penicillium chrysogenum).

parts.question_text: Penicillin is produced commercially in fermenters as shown in Fig. 1.1.

subparts.question_text: Describe how a fermenter can be sterilised.
subparts.hint: Think about methods that kill all microorganisms
subparts.explanation: Fermenters can be sterilized using steam under high pressure (autoclaving), radiation (UV, gamma, or X-rays), or chemical sterilants like bleach.

subparts.question_text: Table 1.1 shows some names of the parts of the fermenter and their functions. Complete Table 1.1. One row has been done for you.
attachments: Table with columns: letter from Fig. 1.1, name, function

correct_answers.answer: Q: nutrient inlet - supplies amino acids
Q: nutrient inlet - supplies nutrients for growth
U: air supply - supplies oxygen for respiration

subparts.hint: Think about the function of each component in maintaining optimal conditions for fermentation
subparts.explanation: Each component of the fermenter has a specific role in maintaining optimal conditions for microorganism growth and product formation.

parts.question_text: Describe what happens to the liquid containing penicillin after it is collected from the fermenter.
parts.explanation: The penicillin must be separated and purified from the fermentation broth through processes like filtration, extraction, crystallization, and drying.

questions.hint: Consider the role of antibiotics in medicine and the industrial production process
questions.explanation: This question covers the medical use of antibiotics, importance of completing treatment, and the industrial fermentation process for producing penicillin.

questions.question_text: Carp are a type of fish. Researchers in Brazil measured the body lengths of a population of carp in a river in 1998 and again in 2008. Histograms of their results are shown in Fig. 2.1.
attachments: Two histograms showing distribution of carp body lengths in 1998 and 2008

correct_answers.answer: group of organisms from one species
number of organisms from one species

parts.hint: Think about what defines a group of organisms as a population
parts.explanation: A population is a group of organisms of the same species living in the same area at the same time.

parts.question_text: Describe the variation in body length of the carp population in 1998. Use the data in Fig. 2.1 to support your answer.

correct_answers.answer: mode is between 12.1 and 16.0 cm long
majority of fish are between 12.1 and 16.0 cm long
very few fish are less than 4 cm
similar number of fish longer and shorter than the mean

parts.hint: Look at the distribution pattern and identify key features
parts.explanation: The 1998 population shows a normal distribution with most fish between 12.1-16.0 cm, ranging from 0-24 cm.

subparts.question_text: The total population of carp in 1998 was 43000 fish. Calculate the total population of carp in 2008. Show your working.
subparts.hint: Add up all the bars from the 2008 histogram
subparts.explanation: Sum all the values from the 2008 histogram: 4 + 8 + 10 + 6 + 4 + 2 = 34 thousand fish.

subparts.question_text: The decrease in the carp population by 2008 was caused by overfishing. Explain how fish stocks can be sustained.
subparts.hint: Think about different conservation methods and regulations
subparts.explanation: Fish stocks can be sustained through quotas, fishing regulations, protected areas, fish farming, and habitat conservation.

subparts.question_text: Body length is an example of continuous variation. Suggest what causes the variation in body length in a population of fish.
subparts.hint: Consider both genetic and environmental influences
subparts.explanation: Continuous variation is caused by both genetic factors (polygenic inheritance) and environmental factors (nutrition, temperature, etc.).

subparts.question_text: Continuous variation is shown with a histogram. Name the type of graph that should be used to show discontinuous variation.
subparts.hint: Think about how discrete categories are displayed
subparts.explanation: Discontinuous variation shows distinct categories with no intermediates, best displayed using a bar chart.

questions.hint: This question tests understanding of populations, variation, and conservation
questions.explanation: The question covers population dynamics, data interpretation from histograms, conservation methods, and types of variation.

questions.question_text: Pepsin is a protease enzyme found in the alimentary canal.
attachments: Diagram showing four test tubes at different pH values with enzyme solution and cubes of cooked egg white

subparts.question_text: Name the product formed from the digestion of proteins by protease enzymes.
subparts.hint: Think about the building blocks of proteins
subparts.explanation: Protease enzymes break down proteins into their constituent amino acids.

subparts.question_text: State the organ in the alimentary canal where pepsin is secreted.
subparts.hint: Think about where protein digestion begins
subparts.explanation: Pepsin is secreted by the gastric glands in the stomach.

parts.question_text: A biologist performed an experiment to find the optimum pH for the activity of pepsin. The enzyme activity was measured in four test-tubes. Each test-tube contained a 1cm³ cube of cooked egg white which contains protein. Fig. 3.1 shows the four test-tubes. The biologist measured the time taken for the complete digestion of the cubes of cooked egg white.

subparts.question_text: The biologist ensured all the cubes of cooked egg white were exactly the same size. Suggest why.
subparts.hint: Consider what needs to be kept constant for a fair test
subparts.explanation: Same size ensures same surface area for enzyme action, making it a controlled variable for valid comparison.

subparts.question_text: Temperature must be controlled in this experiment. Describe how temperature could be controlled.

correct_answers.answer: allow solutions to equilibrate to temperature before experiment
use a thermometer to check the temperature is constant

subparts.hint: Think about equipment used to maintain constant temperature
subparts.explanation: Temperature can be controlled using a water bath or incubator, with thermometer monitoring.

parts.question_text: The same experiment was performed with trypsin, another protease enzyme. Predict the optimum pH for trypsin.
parts.hint: Trypsin works in the small intestine which is alkaline
parts.explanation: Trypsin has an optimum pH of around 8, suitable for the alkaline conditions in the small intestine.

parts.question_text: Enzymes, such as proteases, are important in digestion. Describe in detail how enzymes function, using other digestive enzymes as examples.

correct_answers.answer: enzymes are unchanged in the reaction
lowers the energy needed for the reaction
break down large molecules into small molecules
break down insoluble molecules into soluble molecules
lipase converts lipid to fatty acids and glycerol
lipase converts fats to fatty acids and glycerol
maltase converts maltose to simple sugars

parts.hint: Include enzyme properties, mechanism of action, and specific examples
parts.explanation: Enzymes are protein catalysts that speed up reactions by lowering activation energy. They work through the lock and key mechanism with specific substrates.

questions.hint: Focus on enzyme structure, function, and the factors affecting enzyme activity
questions.explanation: This question tests understanding of digestive enzymes, experimental design, and the factors affecting enzyme activity.

questions.question_text: Type 1 diabetes is caused by the immune system destroying body cells.
attachments: Table 4.1 showing percentage of mice with Type 1 diabetes over time for normal and vitamin D-deficient mice

subparts.question_text: Suggest which organ in the body is attacked by the immune system to cause Type 1 diabetes.
subparts.hint: Which organ produces insulin?
subparts.explanation: In Type 1 diabetes, the immune system attacks the insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas.

subparts.question_text: Antibodies are part of the immune system. Describe how antibodies function.
subparts.hint: Think about how antibodies identify and neutralize pathogens
subparts.explanation: Antibodies recognize specific antigens, bind to them forming complexes, cause agglutination, and mark pathogens for destruction by phagocytes.

subparts.question_text: Describe a cause of vitamin D deficiency in humans.
subparts.hint: Consider both dietary and environmental factors
subparts.explanation: Vitamin D deficiency can be caused by lack of sunlight exposure, dietary insufficiency, or diseases affecting vitamin D metabolism.

subparts.question_text: Describe the effects of vitamin D deficiency in humans.

correct_answers.answer: reduced ability to absorb calcium ions

subparts.hint: Think about bone health and other body systems
subparts.explanation: Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets (soft/bent bones), muscle problems, reduced immunity, and poor calcium absorption.

parts.question_text: Scientists have found that mice can suffer from Type 1 diabetes. They also found that vitamin D affects the development of Type 1 diabetes in mice. Two groups of mice were studied. One group were normal and the other group were vitamin D-deficient. The percentage of mice in each group that developed Type 1 diabetes was recorded every fifty days. Table 4.1 shows their results. Describe the effect of vitamin D deficiency on the development of Type 1 diabetes in mice. Use the data in Table 4.1 to support your answer.

correct_answers.answer: lack of vitamin D leads to more cases of type 1 diabetes in mice
there is no difference in cases until after 50 days
same number of cases until after 50 days
at 100 days there are more cases in vitamin D mice
vitamin D mice levels off before normal mice

parts.hint: Look for patterns and differences between the two groups
parts.explanation: Vitamin D deficiency leads to earlier and higher incidence of Type 1 diabetes in mice, with the deficient group showing more cases from day 100 onwards.

parts.question_text: Suggest the symptoms that mice with Type 1 diabetes would have.
parts.hint: Think about the effects of high blood glucose and lack of insulin
parts.explanation: Type 1 diabetes symptoms include frequent urination, excessive thirst, hunger, fatigue, weight loss, slow healing, and high blood glucose.

parts.question_text: Describe the treatment for human patients with Type 1 diabetes.
parts.hint: Consider both medical treatment and lifestyle management
parts.explanation: Type 1 diabetes is treated with regular insulin injections or pump, blood glucose monitoring, dietary management, and regular exercise.

questions.hint: This question links immune function, vitamin deficiency, and diabetes
questions.explanation: The question explores the relationship between vitamin D deficiency and Type 1 diabetes development, along with symptoms and treatment.

questions.question_text: Fig. 5.1 is an image of a germinating seed showing the growing root.
attachments: Image of germinating seed with root hairs labeled J

parts.question_text: Describe and explain how the structures seen at J are adapted for their function.
parts.hint: Think about the structure-function relationship of root hair cells
parts.explanation: Root hair cells are adapted with long thin extensions increasing surface area for absorption of water by osmosis and minerals by active transport.

subparts.question_text: The root shown in Fig. 5.1 is growing downward into the soil. Name this response seen in roots.
subparts.hint: What is the response to gravity called?
subparts.explanation: Roots show positive gravitropism (also called geotropism), growing in the direction of gravity.

subparts.question_text: Name the chemical that controls this response.
subparts.hint: What plant hormone controls tropisms?
subparts.explanation: Auxin is the plant hormone that controls gravitropic responses in roots.

subparts.question_text: There are situations, either in wild plants or in laboratory experiments, where roots do not grow downwards. Suggest and explain one situation.

correct_answers.answer: in a clinostat - gravity constantly changing
remove root tip - no auxin source
light source below plant - roots grow away from light
anaerobic mud/mangrove swamp - need oxygen for respiration
roots attaching to solid objects for support
material too hard for root to grow through

subparts.hint: Think about environmental conditions or experimental manipulations
subparts.explanation: Roots may not grow downwards in zero gravity, when the gravity stimulus is removed (clinostat), or when other factors override gravitropism.

questions.hint: Focus on adaptations for absorption and plant responses to stimuli
questions.explanation: This question covers root hair cell adaptations for absorption and gravitropic responses in roots controlled by auxin.

questions.question_text: A DNA molecule has two strands as shown in Fig. 6.1.
attachments: Diagram of DNA double helix with base pairing to be completed
DNA sequences of eight plant species for comparison
Classification tree Fig. 6.3 to be completed

subparts.question_text: Fill in the boxes on Fig. 6.1 to show the letter of the bases on strand 2 that will pair with the corresponding bases on strand 1.
subparts.hint: Remember complementary base pairing rules
subparts.explanation: DNA bases pair specifically: Adenine (A) with Thymine (T), and Guanine (G) with Cytosine (C).

subparts.question_text: State the name for the structure of a DNA molecule as shown in Fig. 6.1.
subparts.hint: What is the twisted ladder shape called?
subparts.explanation: DNA has a double helix structure - two strands wound around each other.

parts.question_text: The number of differences between the DNA sequences of the eight species shown in Fig. 6.2 are recorded in Table 6.1. Count the number of differences between the DNA sequences shown in Fig. 6.2 for: • species C and species D • species G and species H. Write your answers in Table 6.1.
parts.hint: Count each position where the bases differ
parts.explanation: Compare the DNA sequences base by base to count the differences between species.

parts.question_text: The most closely related species have the fewest differences between their DNA sequences. State which two plant species shown in Table 6.1 are most distantly related to each other.
parts.hint: Look for the highest number in the table
parts.explanation: The most distantly related species have the most DNA sequence differences.

parts.question_text: The most closely related species have the shortest distance from a branching point on a classification tree. Use the information in Table 6.1 to complete the classification tree in Fig. 6.3. Write the letter corresponding to species B, C, D and G in the box next to the correct branch of the classification tree.
parts.hint: Use the number of differences to determine relationships
parts.explanation: Species with fewer differences should be closer on the tree, sharing more recent common ancestors.

subparts.question_text: A modern method for improving crop productivity is to cut out sections of DNA carrying a useful gene from one organism and place them into another organism. Name the technique of inserting genes from one organism into another.
subparts.hint: What is the process of modifying organisms' genes called?
subparts.explanation: Genetic engineering (also called genetic modification) involves transferring genes between organisms.

subparts.question_text: A gene for producing a vaccine has been inserted into banana plants. Give two other examples in which crop plants have been changed by inserting genes. State one advantage for each example.

correct_answers.answer: salt resistant - extend range where crops can be grown
crop plants produce own insecticides - less insecticide used
β carotene (Golden rice) - increased nutritional value
pharmaceuticals e.g. insulin - cheap production of medicines

subparts.hint: Think about environmental resistance, nutritional improvement, or pest resistance
subparts.explanation: Genetic engineering can improve crop resistance to environmental stresses, pests, and diseases, enhance nutritional value, or produce useful substances.

questions.hint: This question covers DNA structure, sequence comparison, and applications of genetic engineering
questions.explanation: The question tests understanding of DNA base pairing, using DNA sequences for classification, and practical applications of genetic engineering in agriculture.
